events.name: #TwitterData X DSSG
events.description: Please note that this meetup is at our Partner's venue thus the following requirement applies for security reasons.1 - FULL NAME needs to be provided (Otherwise will NOT be admitted).2 - Waitlist will NOT be admitted.  #TwitterDATA Science In Twitter data, you have access to the world’s largest public archive of human thought. That’s over 10 years of Tweets back to 2006. It’s also hundreds of millions of new Tweets rolling in every single day. So, as a marketer or data scientist, what would you do with access to the world's largest archive of human thought that has ever existed? #TwitterDATA Meetup will bring together data scientists, analytics experts, marketing and IT leaders for an evening of inspiration on the power of social data. The event will be hosted at Twitter Singapore, where you will hear from Twitter Data’s Head of Data Science, Dr. Scott Hendrickson (@drskippy), who leads a team of data scientists and strategists working with some of the biggest companies in the world and Ben Truscello (@bentruscello), Head of Global Brands & Agencies for Twitter Data. The session will also include a panel discussion with local data science experts, practitioners, and leaders who will share their experiences in working in the field of data science. (Details will be provided soon!) Plan to stick around for networking! Date: Monday, 20 February 2017 Time: 6-9 PM, Presentations begin promptly at 6:30 PMLocation: Twitter APAC, CapitaGreen Building, 20th Floor RSVP  Opens: 12 Feb 2017, 12pm Closes: 17 Feb 2017, 10am
events.location: Twitter Singapore,  CapitaGreen, 138 Market St, Singapore 048946

events.name: Social Coding
events.description: A space for women coders to learn from each other, to practice and discuss learnings with fellow peers. This would be a weekly event of informal space to do coding. So bring your pet projects along or join one of our existing teams/ projects to work on. Featured Projects:https://trello.com/b/kl2BTwil/wwc-sg-social-coding-projects Newbies Step-by-step Guide Please bring your own laptop. Agenda:6:45p - Introduce projects from members6:55p - Break out into groups7:00p - Start coding! ^_^8:30p - End session There is no food provided, so please make preparations to grab a bite before you turn up. Also, we recommend to bring your own water bottle along. Psst, this event is intended for ladies only. Host:
events.location: #03-04, IDA Labs@NDC 111 Middle Road, National Design Centre, Singapore 188969., IDA Labs@NDC 111 Middle Road, National Design Centre

events.name: PyData Meetup - February 2017
events.description: Agenda  • 6:45pm - 7:00pm Networking • 7:00pm - 8:00pm Presenter: Google’s Tesseract Optical Character Recognition (OCR)   • 8:10pm - 9:00pm Presentation: Deep Learning with Python & TensorFlow Synopsis This talk covers the use of Google’s Tesseract Optical Character Recognition (OCR) Engine to convert scans and images of text into machine-encoded text. The focus of the talk will be on conversion of documents (versus images of scenery with text), and will also cover certain ways we can improve the results obtained from Tesseract. We will be using tesserocr, a Python wrapper for Tesseract API, to achieve OCR the Pythonic way.  Oswell Chan is a recent Computer Science graduate from NUS and works as a Software Developer at Acronis. His interest lies in automation, with a focus to streamline mundane tasks in daily life. His first exposure to OCR was triggered by the problem of trying to ease bill splitting between a big group. Deep Learning with Python & TensorFlow: Python has lots of scientific, data analysis, and machine learning libraries. But there are many problems when starting out on a machine learning project. Which library do you use? How can you use a model that has been trained in your production app? In this talk I will discuss how you can use TensorFlow to create Deep Learning applications and how to deploy them into production. Ian Lewis is a Developer Advocate for Google Cloud Platform based Tokyo, Japan. Ian is a Python and Go developer who is passionate about developer communities. He previously co-founded PyCon JP, the largest Python event in Japan. Ian loves learning about how systems work end-to end and spends his time writing and deploying distributed web apps for his favourite container orchestrator (Kubernetes). Updates •  Join us on Facebook and Twitter  https://www.facebook.com/groups/pydatasg/https://www.twitter.com/pydatasg Sponsors   Group Sponsor
events.location: Google Asia Pacific, Mapletree Business City, 70 Pasir Panjang Rd, Singapore 117371

events.name: February Meetup
events.description:
Hi friends!   We're thrilled to have our third API Craft Singapore meetup on Monday, February the 20th from 7pm. Learn more about APIs in 2017!  Programme  7.00pm: Doors open - mingle over food and drinks 7.20pm: Start of session, opening address by hosts 7.30pm: Start of scheduled talks 9:00pm: Community announcements / End of event  Scheduled Talks - 'Event-Driven APIs' by Yos Riady  - 'Intermediate GraphQL' by Sudheer Jonna 


Information for Attendees Remember to bring a photo ID to get through building security!  The meetup will be hosted at PayPal Singapore, Suntec Tower 5, Level 7 at 5 Temasek Boulevard.  If you're traveling by MRT, the closest MRT stations are CC4 Promenade and CC3 Esplanade. If you're traveling by bus, the closest bus stop is 02159 Opp Suntec Convention Centre. 


Job Opportunities - FitSense is hiring an API developer! Have a job position you'd like to announce? Contact us from the 'Contact' button on the sidebar, and we'll post it here. 


Sponsors Venue sponsor: PayPal Food and drink sponsor: PayPal  Thank you to all our sponsors!  


Community  • Join our Slack group • Join our LinkedIn group
events.location: PayPal Singapore, Suntec Tower 5, 5 Temasek Boulevard, Level 7

events.name: Tech Boleh Tahan: Knit One, Compute One
events.description:
Every beginner knitter learns that there are only two stitches - knit and purl. So knitting is inherently binary, and that opens up a world of possibilities for a coder. Knitted fabric can be used to encode data in a number of ways, from QR code mittens to a fluffy red virus scarf. Patterns themselves become algorithms, and new syntax proposals allow for automated testing, compilers, and even visualisers. Crafters and programmers are working together in the burgeoning Maker scene to hack hardware, create innovative e-textiles, and push the computational limits of sticks and string.

Join us in the evening for the most enriching and inspiring talk by Kristine Howard. Admission is free! Sign up while slots last.

http://ptix.co/2kVh0aK
events.location: OneMaker Group - OMG, 111 Middle Road, #01-02, National Design Centre, Singapore 188969
